message.content:
<<<api>>>: PrintWriter.write
<<<code>>>: 
```java
import java.io.*;

public class PrimeByVector {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        final int NUMBER_PER_LINE = 10;
        int count = 0;
        Vector<Integer> vector = new Vector<>();
        System.out.println("The primes before 92 are: \n");
        
        try {
            PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter(new FileWriter("VectorDump.txt"));
            
            for (int n = 2; n < 92; n++) {
                boolean isPrime = true;
                
                for (int i = 0; i < vector.size(); i++) {
                    int primeNumber = vector.elementAt(i);
                    
                    if (primeNumber > Math.sqrt(n)) {
                        break;
                    }
                    
                    if (n % primeNumber == 0) {
                        isPrime = false;
                        break;
                    }
                }
                
                if (isPrime) {
                    count++;
                    vector.addElement(n);
                    
                    if (count % NUMBER_PER_LINE == 0) {
                        writer.println(n);
                    } else {
                        writer.print(n + " ");
                    }
                }
            }
            
            writer.close();
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}
```

<<<explanation>>>: 
To dump the contents of the vector into a new file called "VectorDump.txt", you can use the PrintWriter class from the java.io package. Here's how you can modify your code to achieve this:

1. Import the necessary classes:
```java
import java.io.*;
```

2. Create a PrintWriter object and pass it a FileWriter object with the file name "VectorDump.txt":
```java
PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter(new FileWriter("VectorDump.txt"));
```

3. Inside the loop where you check for prime numbers, instead of printing the numbers to the console, use the PrintWriter object to write them to the file:
```java
if (count % NUMBER_PER_LINE == 0) {
    writer.println(n);
} else {
    writer.print(n + " ");
}
```

4. Close the PrintWriter object after the loop to ensure that all the data is written to the file:
```java
writer.close();
```

With these modifications, the prime numbers will be written to the "VectorDump.txt" file instead of being displayed on the console.
